thread.title: NFL: Craig Heyward's son recieves NFL fine
thread.title_full: NFL: Craig Heyward's son recieves NFL fine

title: NFL: Craig Heyward's son recieves NFL fine
text:
associated press Steelers lineman Cameron Heyward honored his late dad on his eye black stickers. 
Heyward tweeted Wednesday that the league penalized him for writing "Iron Head" on his eye black during a game. Heyward's father, Craig, spent a decade as a running back in the NFL and went by the nickname "Ironhead" for his physical style of play. 
Passaic's Craig Heyward died in 2006 following a lengthy battle with cancer. He was 39. 
Heyward tweeted: "Got fined for honoring my Dad who bravely fought cancer on my eye black. #NeverGiveUp #CancerSucks" 
As for practice, QB Ben Roethlisberger was a limited participant for the first time since spraining his left MCL on Sept. 27 vs. the Rams. 
TRACKING EX-GIANTS: Raiders coach Jack Del Rio said the MRI on DE Justin Tuck's injured shoulder is "not good," but declined to reveal further details or discuss whether the former Giants lineman would be put on the IR list. 
Tuck has one sack and seven tackles through five games. 
Meanwhile, the Colts re-signed former Giants RB Ahmad Bradshaw, who spent the past two seasons with the team but finished both years on injured reserve. 
PASSING THE TEST? Jaguars QB Blake Bortles fully participated in practice, getting all the starter snaps three days after spraining his throwing shoulder. Bortles said he felt considerably better than he did Monday and gave no reason to keep him on the sideline. … Browns QB Luke McCown, who sprained his left ankle while leading the game-winning drive in overtime to beat the Ravens last week, said he intends to be on the field Sunday vs. the Broncos. He was able to practice Wednesday. 
IN AND OUT: The Falcons said WR Julio Jones (hamstring) was limited at practice and is listed as probable vs. the Saints on Thursday night. … Patriots LT Nate Solder was placed on the IR list, three days after he left the game against the Cowboys with an arm injury. 
AUTOPSY RESULT: Former NFL lineman Adrian Robinson Jr., who killed himself, had a brain disease that has been linked to repeated blows to the head, researchers confirmed. He was 25.
